_exec_summary.SummaryText:
UNION CARBIDE CORPORATION a wholly owned subsidiary of The Dow Chemical Company 



INSTITUTE SITE



The Union Carbide Corporation (UCC) facilities at South Charleston, Institute, Polyolefins Process Research & Development, and New Yard share leveraged support and management and are collectively called West Virginia Operations (WVO).



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



WVO is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such a release should occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. We are also an active member of the Kanawha Putnam Emergency Planning Committee which provides additional emergency response expertise.





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Institute Site is a manufacturing facility that annually produces many specialty chemical products for UCC. Most products are intermediates used in other processes or sold to customers who convert them into finished products. 



There are currently 3 RMP regulated substances present in 35 covered processes at the site. UCC handles and stores threshold quantities of the following RMP-regulated toxic substances at the Institute site:

Ethylene Oxide

Anhydrous Ammonia

Ethylenediamine



Maximum threshold inventory quantities of ethylene oxide have decreased for RMP Processes at Institute due to  deregistration of the Cellosize (Process ID # 1000059210) in 2017 and POLYOX WaterSolubleResins (Process ID # 1000059211), for which ownership has changed to DuPont in 2019.  No other previous maximum threshold quantities have been revised

for the remaining processes. 



Three toxic alternative scenarios are included for this resubmittal.  This has not changed from the 2014 RMP.  



The toxic worst-case scenario for the Institute Site remains unchanged from the 2014 RMP submittal, with exception of changing the quantity of ethylene oxide released from 180,000 lb to 184,000 lb.  This is due to discussions with operations that current cars on site have as much as 182,000 pounds and that 184,000 pounds is conservative.   An additional public receptor was added to include churches which are within the distance to endpoint for the worst-case scenario and checked the box for toxic worst case scenario to include National or State Parks, Forests or Monuments for the inclusion of Kanawha State Forest, which is within this distance. This change did not result in an increased distance to endpoint, but rather due to improved mapping tools. 



Changes were made to Section 1 to reflect changes in Owner or Operator, person responsible for RMP implementation, Emergency Contact, Parent Company web site address, and number of fulltime equivalent employees on site.  Also, a change was made to the longitude and latitude coordinates from a central location to the plant entrance.



The flammable worst case scenario and flammable alternate worst case scenario for POLYOX was removed from the plan, as UCC no longer owns the POLYOX plant.  No other flammable scenarios exist within UCC ownership on site.



Section 7, Program numbers 3 and 5 for CELLOSIZE and POLYOX, respectively, have been removed per discussion above. 



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



UCC facilities at the Institute site have had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years. Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no significant releases with offsite impact as defined by the RMP rule of regulated substances, during this period.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Union Carbide's gene

ral accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA RMP rule, OSHA's PSM standard, and implementation of Dow's Operating Discipline Management System and standards. Key elements include:



Process Safety Information

We maintain detailed records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all covered processes. Examples include, but are not limited to,

Material Safety Data Sheets for all the hazardous chemicals, equipment design specification sheets, and reactive chemicals test results. This information is maintained up-to-date and is available to operating personnel.



Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified, evaluated, and controlled efficiently. The methodologies used to carry out these analyses may include: Checklists, What If/Checklists (combined), Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOPs), Reactive

Chemical/Process Hazard Analyses, Chemical Exposure Index, Fire & Explosion Index, and Layers of Protection

Analyses. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at regular intervals. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.



Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, WVO maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.



Training

WVO has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these proc

esses. Refresher training is provided on a continuing basis.



Mechanical Integrity

WVO carries out a documented Planned Preventative Maintenance Program (PPM) which provides checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes, but is not limited to: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, pumps, and compressors. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change

WVO facilities require management of modifications to process equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions other than "like for like", by identifying, documenting, and reviewing them prior to implementation of changes.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training prior to the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted at WVO. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits

Self-assessments and audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. Audits are conducted using established schedules and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



Incident Investigation

WVO promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a significant release of a regulate

d substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation

UCC believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. UCC employees working in Institute plants are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.



Contractors

WVO hires contractors to perform some specialized maintenance, distribution, and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is performed. WVO has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes he/she may encounter while on site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Kanawha Putnam Emergency Planning Committee (KPEPC) and the community.



The Institute site has a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post- incident decontamination of affected areas. The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent cha

nges taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.



To ensure proper functioning, quarterly emergency drills are conducted to enhance skills and tactics for responding to an accidental chemical release. Critiques are held on drills and actual events. Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.



KPEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which Institute's emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

We continue to implement projects to improve process safety as opportunities are identified via external regulatory changes and/or internal process safety program changes or evaluations.
